user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarSignal_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarSignal_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_cond_signal(&impl->cv);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarSignal_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int32 OS_CondVarSignal(osal_id_t var_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CondVarSignal_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The listed fragments are the points where function calls and macro expansion form the call graph relevant to Rule 17.2 and therefore should be investigated for possible direct or indirect recursion: the implementation (OS_CondVarSignal_Impl), the macro used to obtain the object record (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET), the inline index accessor (OS_ObjectIndexFromToken), and the public wrapper that obtains a token and calls the impl (OS_CondVarSignal). Other pieces of the provided code do not need investigation for recursion: local variable declarations, simple return statements, and the trivial getter OS_ObjectIndexFromToken (its body is a single field access) do not introduce calls that could create recursion. The only external call from OS_CondVarSignal_Impl is pthread_cond_signal — this is a POSIX API call and, in normal implementations, does not call back into these OS_* functions, so it is not a likely source of indirect recursion. The primary additional candidate that must be examined (not provided here) is the implementation of OS_ObjectIdGetById and any functions it calls, because that function is invoked before OS_CondVarSignal_Impl and could, in principle, call back into OS_CondVarSignal or related functions; include its definition in the investigation. No other fragments in the supplied code introduce calls that could create direct or indirect self-calls.
